awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Validation of a Floating Wind Turbine Platform Optimized for Low Cost and Extensive Deployment
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is to develop a technology that delivers low cost of energy from offshore wind and unlocks new markets inaccessible to current technology, e.g., small populations with smaller, locally-maintained turbines, deep water locations where conventional floaters are not economical, and regions lacking deep ports. If successful, the global impact may have the potential to suppress carbon emissions at the scale of gigaton carbon dioxide (CO2) equivalent/year. The proposed technology is a floating wind turbine that may reduce 80% of the weight of a conventional floating turbine and makes it possible to fabricate more components locally, with domestic businesses and jobs. The newly proposed architecture will be tested to ensure it survives and operates well in the ocean environment. The crucial first step is to adapt the National Renewable Energy Laboratory’s (NREL) world-class wind-wave software to simulate the unusual motions of the system and demonstrate its viability. The end goal is the commercialization of a disruptive offshore wind turbine, developed in the U.S. and deployed globally, that can outcompete all of today’s designs, in a market estimated to soon reach ~$100 billion/year.

This project seeks provide the intellectual foundation that leads to a first-of-its-kind class of offshore wind turbines that have minimal weight, that rides on top of the waves, taht expands deployability into regions inaccessible with current technology, and that increases mobility for installation / maintenance. Such a floating structure has never before been designed and this project may provide deep insight into several questions about the loading and motions that arise from a complex superposition of turbulent wind, random waves, ocean current, rotor elasticity and angular momentum, and dynamic blade pitch and generator control. This STTR proposal seeks to address a critical technical risk: adaptation of NREL’s simulator OpenFAST to characterize the unique motions of the system operating in a complex environment of loading from wave, wind and current and the resulting impacts on loading and power production. The proposed system departs from long-standing industry conventions that have relied on the design principle of limiting system motions. The results of the simulator may be used to refine the system design and then demonstrate that it's dynamic behavior complies with the design load cases required for certification.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Successful commercialization of the floating T-Omega Wind system will generate several BROADER IMPACTS, including:

  • Lower cost of renewable electricity
  • Technical and economic feasibility in a wider range of (1) water depths, (2) metocean conditions, (3) market size, and (4) infrastructure availability. This will unlock markets that are small or lack good ports and regions with greater depth, enlarging the scope of offshore wind electricity.
  • Uniquely designed for local construction (hence local jobs) and fabrication and enhanced maintenance safety and speed. For U.S. deployments, the TOW system can be fabricated with greater domestic content.

The INTELLECTUAL MERIT comes from identifying and exploring a new region of floating wind turbine design space – that of a lighter, wave-following floating platform allied with a motion-tolerant rotor and control software, and compliant mooring. This upends many design trends, including large drafts, limited mobility, specialized launching and repair capabilities -- all factors driving existing turbines to greater size. Others include system natural frequencies higher than wave frequencies, reduced importance of fatigue resistance, and reduced need for site-specific engineering. These are different than the current perspectives and design techniques related to lifetime durability.

Our project therefore results in a first-of-its-kind understanding of a high motion operational regime, and develops a first-of-its-kind simulation capability, freely available to the larger community.

OUTCOMES  OF AWARD

NREL customized its open-source software OpenFAST to address a new style of floating turbine with multi-leg towers. Such a configuration when allied with light shallow-draft floats offers an opportunity to reduce platform weight/cost by a factor of 5, with implications for electricity cost, local jobs, needed port deepening, etc.

We developed technical specifications of a preliminary concept system, and used this to explore both software functioning and potential issues of the concept.

The design was revised to reduce motion and stress, and then NREL produced high quality transfer functions (RAOs) for hundreds of relevant output variables.

We were able to use efficient frequency domain methods to estimate ultimate design values for generically severe metocean conditions.  Such conditions are expected to exceed design conditions at most planned wind farms, but we wanted to affirm that an inexpensive design can tolerate severe conditions.

This approach affirmed the preliminary structural and mooring design, though a few members had to be strengthened. The work resulted in a paper submitted to the IOWTC conference and a presentation at the NAWEA conference.

The computer we purchased allows us to run simulations using the customized NREL software.

The naval architect we hired led the development of a Qualification Basis, verified by certification authority DNV, and also provided classical intact stability results for our novel hull shape.

NREL produced a simplified controller and demonstrated general suitability to simulate industry-specified design load cases.

STTR results have intrigued a major turbine OEM, who embedded a senior engineer in our weekly technical meetings.

 


Last Modified: 11/11/2023
Modified by: Jeremy Papadopoulos

Images (1 of )
  • Fig.2 SUBDYN beam model of platform in OpenFAST. The turbine axle is a key structural member, and the legs are designed to be primarily compressive members.
    NREL
    Copyrighted
    Jeremy Papadopoulos
    OpenFAST Model
  • Fig.5 Frequency methods incorporating the extreme metocean conditions were used to estimate peak hub accelerations � a key turbine design parameter. Blue curve with high peak relates to 70m float spacing with rigid components. Middle large-dash curve reflects 100m spacing and elastic flexibility in
    NREL
    Copyrighted
    Jeremy Papadopoulos
    Behavior Changes
  • Fig.1 Rendering of the TOW concept with widely spaced shallow-draft floats, two upwind legs plus two downwind legs, a direct drive generator, and a single mooring line aiming at the center of the rotor. This novel morphology reduces system weight ~80% at the cost of magnifying wave motion.
    TOW
    Copyrighted
    Jeremy Papadopoulos
    TOW System Rendering
  • Fig.4 Initial design with 70m float spacing (light grey) was revised (to 100m, dark grey) in order to avoid pitch forcing at pitch resonance period. Structure is altered to reduce leg bending moments and mooring line stretch.
    TOW
    Copyrighted
    Jeremy Papadopoulos
    Design Changes
  • Fig.3 Detail of platform connection to ELASTODYN turbine model, ensuring correct loading is experienced by the novel multi-tower structure.
    NREL
    Copyrighted
    Jeremy Papadopoulos
    OpenFAST Model Details

Uniquely designed for local construction (hence local jobs) and fabrication and enhanced maintenance safety and speed. For U.S. deployments, the TOW system can be fabricated with greater domestic content.
